| casualties2 = | casualties3 = | casualties_label = Arrests, casualties{{Clarify|date=April 2011}} | notes = }} The '''2011 Saudi Arabian protests''' have been influenced by the [[Arab Spring]] that started with the 2011 [[Tunisian revolution]]. One of the main online organisers of a planned 11 March "Day of Rage", Faisal Ahmed Abdul-Ahad (or Abdul-Ahadwas), was alleged to have been killed by [[Ministry of Interior (Saudi Arabia)|Saudi security forces]] on 2 March, by which time one of the [[Facebook]] groups discussing the plans had over 26,000 members. Small protests over [[labor rights]] took place in April in front of government ministry buildings in [[Riyadh]], [[Taâif]] and [[Tabuk]]. Protests, made up mainly of [[Shia]] protesters,http://www.ibtimes.com/articles/135126/20110416/saudi-arabia-shias-protest-sunni.htm occurred in [[Qatif]] and smaller cities in the [[Eastern Province, Saudi Arabia|Eastern Province]] such as [[al-Awamiyah]], and [[Hofuf]] in April and May. They called for the release of prisoners, for the [[Peninsula Shield Force]] to be withdrawn from Bahrain, for equal representation in key offices and for reforms in political positions, as they feel marginalised. Women organised a [[Facebook]] [[women's suffrage]] campaign called "Baladi", stating that Saudi Arabian law gives women electoral rights. In April, women in [[Jeddah]], Riyadh and [[Dammam]] tried to register as electors for the [[Saudi Arabian municipal elections, 2011|22 September municipal elections]] despite officials stating that women could not participate. In May and June, [[Manal al-Sharif]] and other women organised a women's right-to-drive campaign, with the main action to take place on 17 June. Al-Sharif drove a car in May and was detained on 22 May and from 23â30 May. Other women also drove cars, including actress Wajnat Rahbini, who was arrested after driving in Jeddah on 4 June and released a day later. ==Background== {{main|Politics of Saudi Arabia}} The politics of Saudi Arabia takes place in a framework of a particular form of [[absolute monarchy]] whereby the [[King of Saudi Arabia]] is both [[head of state]] and the [[head of government]], but where decisions are to a large extent made on the basis of consultation among the senior princes, with the King functioning as ''primus inter pares'' and ultimate arbiter. The Basic Law adopted in 1992 declared that Saudi Arabia is a monarchy ruled by the male descendants of King [[Abd Al Aziz Al Saud]], and that the [[Qur'an]] is the constitution of the country, which is governed on the basis of [[Islam]]ic law ([[Sharia|Shari'a]]). An unidentified 65-year-old man died on 21 January after setting himself on fire in the town of [[Samtah]], [[Jizan]]. This was apparently the kingdom's first known case of self-immolation.{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12260465|title=Man dies after setting himself on fire in Saudi Arabia|date=23 January 2011 |work=|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=23 January 2011 }}{{cite web|url=http://sundaytimes.lk/world-news/4231-man-dies-in-possible-first-self-immolation-in-saudi|title=Man dies in possible first self-immolation in Saudi |first=Mohideen |last=Mifthah |date=22 January 2011 |work=|publisher=[[The Sunday Times (Sri Lanka)]]|accessdate=23 January 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wut1kRgo |archivedate=3 February 2011 |deadurl=no }} ==Protests== ===Timeline=== ====29 January==== On 29 January, hundreds of protesters gathered in the city of [[Jeddah]] in a rare display of criticism against the city's poor infrastructure after deadly floods swept through the city, killing eleven people.{{cite web|url=http://www.montrealgazette.com/news/Flood+sparks+rare+action/4189873/story.html|title=Flood sparks rare action|date=29 January 2011 |work=|publisher=[[The Gazette (Montreal)|Montreal Gazette]] |accessdate=29 January 2011 }} Police stopped the demonstration about 15 minutes after it started. About 30 to 50 people were arrested.{{cite news | title=Dozens detained in Saudi over flood protests | date=29 January 2011 | publisher=[[The Peninsula (newspaper)|The Peninsula]] (Qatar)/[[Thomson-Reuters]] | url=http://www.thepeninsulaqatar.com/middle-east/140720-dozens-detained-in-saudi-over-flood-protests.html |accessdate=31 January 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5w9qUZeyR |archivedate=31 January 2011 |deadurl=no }} On the same day, an online campaign started on [[Facebook]], making demands that included calling for Saudi Arabia to become a constitutional monarchy, and for "an end to corruption, an even distribution of wealth, and a serious solution for unemployment". ====5 February==== On 5 February, about 40 women wearing black clothes demonstrated in [[Riyadh]], calling for the release of prisoners held without trial.{{cite news | first1=Ulf | last1=Laessing |first2=Asma |last2=Alsharif | pages= | language =| title=Saudi women protest, web activists call for reform | date=5 February 2011 | publisher=[[Swiss Info]]/[[Thomson Reuters]] | url=http://www.swissinfo.ch/eng/news/international/Saudi_women_protest,_web_activists_call_for_reform.html?cid=29428092 |accessdate=16 February 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wYAoCCPC |archivedate=16 February 2011 |deadurl=no }} ====10 February==== On 10 February, a [[Thomson Reuters]] report claimed that 10 intellectuals, [[human rights in Saudi Arabia|human rights]] activists and lawyers came together to create the [[Umma Islamic Party]] â considered to be the first political party in Saudi Arabia since the 1990s â to demand the end of [[absolute monarchy]] in the country.{{cite news | first=Ulf | last=Laessing| pages= | language =| title=Pro-reform Saudi activists launch political party | date=10 February 2011 | publisher=[[Thomson Reuters]] | url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/10/us-saudi-opposition-idUSTRE71942L20110210?sp=true |accessdate=11 February 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wQOpuC8A |archivedate=11 February 2011 |deadurl=no }} On 18 February, all ten founding members of the party were arrested and ordered to withdraw demands for political reform in exchange for their release.{{cite news |url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/02/18/AR2011021802641.html |title=Saudi authorites detain founders of new party |publisher=Washington Post |date=18 February 2011 |accessdate=19 February 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5whAiOr55 |archivedate=22 February 2011 |deadurl=no}} ====17 February==== According to Reuters Africa, a small protest was held by Shia in the small town of [[al-Awamiyah]], near [[Qatif]] in the Eastern Province{{cite news|url=http://af.reuters.com/article/egyptNews/idAFLDE71J0NZ20110220?sp=true |title=Three Saudi Shi'ites released after rare protest |publisher=Reuters |date=20 February 2011 |accessdate=3 April 2011}} to demand the release of three political prisoners held since protests in the town on March 19, 2009 protesting an arrest warrant against the town's Shia imam, Sheikh Nimr Bagir al Namr. The prisoners were identified as Ali Ahmad al Faraj, the sheikh's 16-year old nephew, and two others, Ali Salih Abdul Jabbar and Makki Al Abbas.{{cite web|url=http://www.hns-info.net/spip.php?article17955 |title=Des hommes et des adolescents chiites maintenus au secret par les autoritÃ©s saoudiennes |publisher=HNS-info |date=|accessdate=3 April 2011}}{{fr icon}} The three prisoners were released on February 20. ====24 February==== A protest was held in [[Qatif]] by Shi'a Muslims to demand the release of additional political prisoners. {{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/2/8/6478/World/Region/Saudi-Shiites-stage-another-protest-in-oil-provinc.aspx |title=Saudi Shi'ites stage another protest in oil province |publisher=Ahram Online |date=26 February 2011 |accessdate=3 April 2011}} Video posted to YouTube confirms the existence and location of the protest, showing the roundabout 350 meters south of Ohud Road on King Abdelaziz Road.[http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hrLvW9kmBOM&feature=related YouTube â â«ÙØ¸Ø§ÙØ±Ø§Øª Ø§ÙÙØ·ÙÙ ÙÙØ§ÙØ±Ø§Ø¬ Ø¹Ù Ø§ÙØ³Ø¬ÙØ§Ø¡ Ø§ÙÙÙØ³ÙÙâ¬â]{{dead link|date=April 2011}} ====25 February==== A group called ''Jeddah Youth for Change'' called for a rally in [[Jeddah]] on 25 February.{{cite web|url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail/166978.html |title=Saudi youths call for rally in Jeddah |publisher=PressTV |date=25 February 2011 |accessdate=3 April 2011}} ====Late February==== Brian Whitaker of ''[[The Guardian]]'' interpreted{{cite news | first=Brian | last=Whitaker | pages= | language =| title=Saudi Arabia's subtle protests are serious | date=1 March 2011 | publisher=The Guardian | url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/commentisfree/2011/mar/01/saudi-arabia-protests-middle-east |accessdate=2 March 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wtJo0K7m |archivedate=2 March 2011 |deadurl=no }} the creation of a website for people to publish complaints about government services, "shakra.com",{{cite news | first= | last= | pages= | language =| title=Site lets public air grievances about services | date=26 February 2011 | publisher=[[Arab News]] | url=http://arabnews.com/saudiarabia/article287105.ece |accessdate=2 March 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wtOlF8F5 |archivedate=2 March 2011 |deadurl=no }} the circulation of at least three [[internet|online]] petitions calling for political and legal reforms and a call for reform that is "the result of meaningful interaction and dialogue among the different components of a society" by Prince [[Al-Waleed bin Talal]]{{cite news | first= | last=Al-Waleed bin Talal | pages= |authorlink=Al-Waleed bin Talal| language =| title=A Saudi Prince's Plea for Reform | date=24 February 2011 | publisher=New York Times | url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/25/opinion/25alsaud.html?_r=1 |accessdate=2 March 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wtPXILKF |archivedate=2 March 2011 |deadurl=no }} as protest actions that "in a Saudi context [are] momentous". ====3â4 March==== About 100 people, mostly men, and one group of women, marched in [[Al-Awamiyah]] and [[Qatif]] in the [[Eastern Province, Saudi Arabia|Eastern Province]], protesting against prisoners held without trial, calling out "Peaceful, peaceful".{{cite news | first=Ulf | last=Laessing |coauthors=Elizabeth Fullerton | pages= | language =| title=Shi'ites stage small protest in Saudi oil province | date=3 March 2011 | publisher=[[Thomson Reuters]] | url=http://af.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idAFTRE72259V20110303?sp=true |accessdate=3 March 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wxYBeY1v |archivedate=5 March 2011 |deadurl=no }} In Qatif, 22 of the protestors were arrested. Police responses in Qatif included attacks on women protestors.{{cite news | first= | last= | pages= | language =| title=Massive protests loom in Saudi Arabia | date=5 March 2011 | publisher=[[Press TV]] | url=http://www.presstv.com/detail/168262.html |accessdate=3 March 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wxlexNuX |archivedate=5 March 2011 |deadurl=no }} Protests following Friday 4 March prayers took place in [[Riyadh]] and [[Hofuf]].{{cite news | first=DB/HRF | last= | pages= | language =| title=Anti-govt. protests hit S Arabia cities | date=5 March 2011 | publisher=[[Press TV]] | url=http://www.presstv.com/detail/168261.html |accessdate=3 March 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wxZ3aAm7 |archivedate=5 March 2011 |deadurl=no }} In Riyadh, at least 3 people were arrested after criticising the monarchy. Both alarmed and annoyed by such action, the Saudi government reminded citizens that public protesting was banned, and that the ban would be strictly enforced.{{cite news|last=Banerjee |first=Neela |url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fg-saudi-protest-20110306,0,3128624.story?track=rss |title=Saudi Arabia protests: Saudi Arabia warns it will enforce ban on protests |newspaper=Los Angeles Times |date=6 March 2011 |accessdate=3 April 2011}} ====9â10 March==== Protests took place in the evening of 9 March in Qatif. About 600â800 protestors were present at a similar protest on the evening of 10 March, calling for nine prisoners to be released.{{cite news | first=Sarah | last=el Deeb | pages= | language =| title=Saudi police open fire at protest | date=10 March 2011 | publisher=The Washington Post/[[Associated Press|AP]] | url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/03/10/AR2011031003269.html |accessdate=10 March 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5x5UDstQp |archivedate=10 March 2011 |deadurl=no }}{{cite news | first= Ian| last= Black| pages= | language =| title=Saudi expectations high before Friday's 'day of rage' protests | date=10 March 2011 | publisher=The Guardian | url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/mar/10/saudi-expectations-high-day-rage |accessdate=10 March 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5x5TA9Dd0 |archivedate=10 March 2011 |deadurl=no }} About 200 police were present. The police used "percussion bombs" and shot at protestors with gunfire for about 10 minutes. Three protestors were injured and hospitalised with "moderate" injuries.{{cite news | first= | last= | pages= | language =| title=Saudi police wound 3 Shiite protesters: witness | date=10 March 2011 | publisher=[[France 24]]/[[Agence France Presse|AFP]] | url=http://www.france24.com/en/20110310-saudi-police-wound-3-shiite-protesters-witness |accessdate=10 March 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5x5VXfe7K |archivedate=10 March 2011 |deadurl=no }} ====11 March â "Day of Rage"==== A "Day of Rage" was planned by Saudi Arabians on 11 March{{cite news | first= Richard |last=Spencer |coauthors= James Kirkup, Nabila Ramdani | pages= | language =| title=Libya: Muammar Gaddafi's regime on the brink of collapse | date=21 February 2011 | publisher=The Daily Telegraph | url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/libya/8339435/Libya-Muammar-Gaddafis-regime-on-the-brink-of-collapse.html |accessdate=22 February 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wh6l0B7O |archivedate=22 February 2011 |deadurl=no }} at noon in solidarity with protests in Libya and Bahrain.{{cite web|url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail/166931.html |title=Saudis plan pro-democracy rally |publisher=PressTV |date=25 February 2011 |accessdate=3 April 2011}} A ''[[Facebook]]'' page called for a "March 11 Revolution of Longing" and included demands for "the ousting of the regime" and for the national leader and the [[Consultative Assembly of Saudi Arabia]] to be chosen by election.{{cite news | first=Ammar | last=Awad | pages= | language =| title=Protests continue across the Arab world | date=23 February 2011 | publisher=[[Toronto Star]]/[[Thomson Reuters]]/[[Associated Press|AP]] | url=http://www.thestar.com/news/world/article/943434--protests-continue-across-the-arab-world |accessdate=24 February 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wk3pvTMz |archivedate=24 February 2011 |deadurl=no }} It also called for elections for national leadership, more [[women's rights in Saudi Arabia|women's rights]] and for freeing [[Human rights in Saudi Arabia#Political freedom|political prisoners]].{{cite news | first= | last= | pages= | language =| title=Middle East unrest: Saudi and Bahraini kings offer concessions | date=23 February 2011 | publisher=The Guardian | url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/feb/23/middle-east-unrest-concessions |accessdate=24 February 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wtU78Xzb |archivedate=2 March 2011 |deadurl=no }} As of 5 March, one of the ''Facebook'' groups calling for the Day of Rage had about 26,000 members.{{cite news | first=Sara | last=E | pages= | language =| title=Saudi Facebook Administrator Faisal Ahmed Abdul-Ahadwas reportedly shot as Saudi Arabia bans protests ahead of its Day of Rage | date=6 March 2011 | publisher=EU-digest | url=http://eu-digest.blogspot.com/2011/03/faisal-ahmed-abdul-ahadwas-saudi.html |accessdate=9 March 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5x3J2Tg1Y |archivedate=9 March 2011 |deadurl=no }} On 11 March itself, protests continued for the third day in a row in Qatif and extended to Hofuf and al-Amawiyah, with several hundred protestors participating in the three protests.{{cite news | first= Neela| last= Banerjee| pages= | language =| title=Saudi Arabia 'day of rage' protest fizzles | date=11 March 2011 | publisher= | url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fg-saudi-unrest-20110312,0,72557.story |accessdate=11 March 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5x76tP4d2 |archivedate=11 March 2011 |deadurl=no | work=Los Angeles Times}} In Jeddah, ''[[The Los Angeles Times]]'' and ''[[Agence France Presse]]'' reported heavy military and police patrolling and an absence of protests. In Riyadh, the police presence was "overwhelming" by early in the morning of 11 March, with large numbers of police cars present and helicopters that "crisscrossed the skies all day". One person, [[Khaled al-Johani]], walked past [[BBC Arabic Television]] journalists twice and both times was threatened by police that he would be imprisoned if he walked past the journalists, who were accompanied by state escorts, a third time.{{Citation needed|date=June 2011}} He stated, "I'm here to say we need democracy, we need freedom. We need to speak freely. We will reach out, the government doesn't own us. I was afraid to speak, but no more. We don't have dignity, we don't have justice!" He stated that there is no [[freedom of the press]] in [[Saudi Arabia]], since it is an [[absolute monarchy]], and that living a dignified life in [[Saudi Arabia]] depends on an individual's connection and mercy of [[Al-Saud]] princes.{{citation needed|date=June 2011}} After stating his opinion, al-Johani stated his worry that he would be detained before returning home and said that the journalists could visit him at [[al-Ha'ir Prison|al-Ha'ir]] or [[`Ulaysha Prison]]. Al-Johani was detained after he returned home and was not allowed any contact with his family for 58 days. {{As of|2011|04|20}}, al-Johani was being held at `Ulaysha Prison. After visiting al-Johani in May, family members said that he had lost weight and was depressed. ''[[AOL]] News'' said that al-Johani became a "folk hero in the blink of an eye" when the BBC broadcast al-Johani's full statement in April and a six-minute video "Where is Khaled?" was uploaded to [[YouTube]]. According to Mohammad al-Qahtani of the [[Saudi Civil and Political Rights Association]], al-Johani became known online as "the only brave man in Saudi Arabia". ====13 March==== More than 200 people protested outside of the [[Ministry of Interior (Saudi Arabia)|Ministry of the Interior]] in Riyadh on Sunday 13 March, asking for information about prisoners and their immediate release.{{cite news | first= | last= | pages= | language =| title=Saudis protest outside Interior Ministry | date=13 March 2011 | publisher=[[The News Tribune]]/[[Associated Press|AP]] | url=http://www.thenewstribune.com/2011/03/13/1582849/saudis-organize-outside-interior.html |accessdate=17 March 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5xG836rzV |archivedate=17 March 2011 |deadurl=no }}{{cite news | first=Simon | last=Tisdall | pages= | language =| title=Saudi Arabia polices the region as trouble stirs at home | date=14 March 2011 | publisher=The Guardian | url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/commentisfree/2011/mar/14/saudi-arabia-bahrain-iran-us |accessdate=17 March 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5xG83Z0lN |archivedate=17 March 2011 |deadurl=no }} Protestor Ahmed Ali said that his brother has been imprisoned for four years and nothing is known about him nor the charges against him. Another protestor said that his father has been in prison for 10 years without receiving medical attention for his colon cancer nor a trial. The protestors asked to meet with the Minister for the Interior Prince [[Nayef bin Abdul-Aziz Al Saud]]. The request was refused and entry to the Ministry building was refused. ====15â18 March==== On 15 March, about 1000 people protested in Qatif calling for the [[Peninsula Shield Force]] to be withdrawn from Bahrain, where it is being used against [[2011 Bahraini protests|Bahraini protestors]].{{cite news | first=Donna | last=Abu Nasr | pages= | language =| title=Saudi Arabia Demonstrators Hold Rallies in al-Qatif, Awwamiya | date=16 March 2011 | publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] | url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-03-16/saudi-arabia-demonstrators-hold-rallies-in-al-qatif-awwamiya.html |accessdate=18 March 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5xHj2ny3J |archivedate=18 March 2011 |deadurl=no }} A related protest took place in al-Awamiyah. Hundreds of people protested in Qatif and the nearby region on 16 March, calling for the release of prisoners and expressing support for the Bahraini protestors.{{cite news | first= | last= | pages= | language =| title=Saudi Shi'ites protest, support Bahrain brethren | date=16 March 2011 | publisher=[[Thomson Reuters]] | url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/03/16/us-bahrain-saudi-protests-idUSTRE72F8ZB20110316 |accessdate=17 March 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5xGAhIzV4 |archivedate=17 March 2011 |deadurl=no }} Anti-riot forces were present at the protests. The Qatif demonstration lasted for about half an hour. Protestors called for the Peninsula Shield Force to be withdrawn from Bahrain. The protests continued the following day, 17 March, in and near Qatif, with similar demands, and about 4000 protestors in Qatif.{{cite news | first= | last= | pages= | language =| title=Several injured in Saudi Arabia protest | date=2011-03 | publisher=[[Press TV]] | url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail/170496.html |accessdate=18 March 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5xHkV8dvZ |archivedate=18 March 2011 |deadurl=no }} Police fired rubber bullets and several people were injured. One slogan used in the protests was "Bahrain Free Free. Saudi forces out!".{{cite news | first=Jason | last=Benham | pages= | language =| title=Saudi Shi'ites call for Bahrain troop withdrawal | date=17 March 2011 | publisher=[[Thomson Reuters]] | url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/03/17/us-saudi-protests-idUSTRE72G7JQ20110317 |accessdate=17 March 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5xGBKJvGP |archivedate=17 March 2011 |deadurl=no }} Similar protests took place on Friday 18 March, in [[Qatif]], [[Omran]], [[al-Awamiyah]] (about 2500 protestors), [[Safwa City]] and [[Qatif#Towns and villages|al-Rabeeya]] (1000 protestors each).{{cite news | first= | last= | pages= | language =| title=Kuwait Navy set for Bahrain - Saudi Shias Rally | date=18 March 2011 | publisher=[[Arab Times]] | url=http://www.arabtimesonline.com/NewsDetails/tabid/96/smid/414/ArticleID/166871/t/Kuwait-Navy-set-for-Bahrain/Default.aspx |accessdate=19 March 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5xIz3sxxL |archivedate=19 March 2011 |deadurl=no }} Ten people in Omran were injured from being hit by police batons. One of the slogans in Qatif was "One people not two people â the people of Qatif and Bahrain!"{{cite news | first= | last= | pages= | language =| title=Shi'ites protest peacefully in eastern Saudi Arabia | date=18 March 2011 | publisher=[[Jerusalem Post]]/[[Thomson Reuters]] | url=http://www.jpost.com/Headlines/Article.aspx?id=212802 |accessdate=18 March 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5xHk9zw1s |archivedate=18 March 2011 |deadurl=no }} ====20 Marchâ1 April==== Calls for protests on 20 March were made on a Facebook page in late February.{{cite news | first=Carolyn | last=Cohn |coauthor=Sebastian Tong | pages= | language =| title= Saudi, Bahraini debt insurance costs rise â Markit| date=2 March 2011 | publisher=[[Thomson Reuters]] | url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/03/02/mideast-swaps-idUSLDE7210LL20110302 |accessdate=2 March 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wtTG0zyW |archivedate=2 March 2011 |deadurl=no }} On 20 March, about 100 people demonstrated outside the [[Ministry of Interior|Ministry of the Interior]] in Riyadh, calling for family members imprisoned without trial to be released,{{cite news | first= | last= | pages= | language =| title=Saudi Arabia police break up small protest | date=20 March 2011 | publisher=United Press International | url=http://www.upi.com/Top_News/World-News/2011/03/20/Saudi-Arabia-police-break-up-small-protest/UPI-76921300636402/ |accessdate=21 March 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5xMKeHkLO |archivedate=21 March 2011 |deadurl=no }} for the third time in March,{{cite news | first= | last= | pages= | language =| title=Saudi protest ends with arrests | date=21 March 2011 | publisher=[[Al Jazeera English]] | url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/03/2011320112126999266.html |accessdate=21 March 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5xMP59raA |archivedate=21 March 2011 |deadurl=no }} following similar protests on 4 March and 13 March. The demonstrators tried to enter the Ministry building,{{cite news | first= Martin| last= Chulov| pages= | language =| title=Egyptians endorse reforms but Arab discontent simmers | date=21 March 2011 | publisher=The Guardian | url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/mar/21/egyptians-endorse-reform-arab-discontent |accessdate=21 March 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5xMMKgXIH |archivedate=21 March 2011 |deadurl=no }} which was surrounded by about 50 police cars.{{cite news | first= | last= | pages= | language =| title=Saudi police break up protest outside Riyadh interior ministry | date=21 March 2011 | publisher=[[International Business Times]] | url=http://uk.ibtimes.com/articles/125014/20110321/saudi-arabia.htm |accessdate=21 March 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5xMMDK67z |archivedate=21 March 2011 |deadurl=no }} About 15 to 50{{cite news | first= | last= | pages= | language =| title=Women remain barred from voting as Saudi Arabia announces elections | date=23 March 2011 | publisher=[[The National (Abu Dhabi)]]/[[Associated Press|AP]]/[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] | url=http://www.thenational.ae/news/worldwide/middle-east/women-remain-barred-from-voting-as-saudi-arabia-announces-elections |accessdate=22 March 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5xNr7T4Xv |archivedate=22 March 2011 |deadurl=no }} protestors were arrested. Hundreds demonstrated in Qatif on 20 March against the use of the [[Peninsula Shield Force]] troops from the six [[Cooperation Council for the Arab States of the Gulf|Gulf Cooperation Council]] states{{cite news | first=Muqbil | last=al-Saeri | pages= | language =| title=A talk with Peninsula Shield force commander Mutlaq Bin Salem al-Azima | date=2011-03 | publisher=[[Asharq al-Awsat]] | url=http://aawsat.com/english/news.asp?section=3&id=24676 |accessdate=29 March 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5xYJcDTUV |archivedate=29 March 2011 |deadurl=no }} against the [[2011 Bahraini uprising]].{{cite news | first=Cynthia | last=Johnston |coauthors=Samia Nakhoul | pages= | language =| title=Saudi Shi'ite protests simmer as Bahrain conflict rages | date=21 March 2011 | publisher=[[Thomson Reuters]] | url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/03/21/us-saudi-shiites-idUSTRE72K1H220110321?sp=true |accessdate=21 March 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5xMMfK4ii |archivedate=21 March 2011 |deadurl=no }} ''[[Thomson Reuters]]'' described the intervention in Bahrain as having caused the protests to intensify, reporting an incident in which the second home of Sheikh Wajeeh al-Awjami, a judge calling for street protests to stop, was burnt by angry youths. Similar protests by hundreds of people in villages near Qatif took place on Friday 25 March {{cite news | first=Jason | last=Benham | pages= | language =| title=Hundreds of Saudi Shi'ites protest in east | date=25 March 2011 | publisher=[[Thomson Reuters]] | url=http://ca.reuters.com/article/topNews/idCATRE72O3RL20110325?sp=true |accessdate=25 March 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5xSLWasoJ |archivedate=25 March 2011 |deadurl=no }} and again in Qatif{{cite news | first= | last= | pages= | language =| title=Saudi demonstrators hold rally in Qatif | date=1 April 2011 | publisher=[[Press TV]] | url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail/172590.html |accessdate=2 April 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5xeV9lhbt |archivedate=2 April 2011 |deadurl=no }} and al-Awamiyah{{cite news | first=Jason | last=Benham |coauthors=Janet Lawrence | pages= | language =| title=Saudi Shi'ites protest peacefully in east | date=1 April 2011 | publisher=[[Thomson Reuters]] | url=http://ca.reuters.com/article/topNews/idCATRE7304C920110401?sp=true |accessdate=2 April 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5xeV902KM |archivedate=2 April 2011 |deadurl=no }} on 1 April. ====5 April==== About a hundred literacy campaign teachers held a street demonstration outside the [[Council of Ministers of Saudi Arabia|Ministry of Civil Services]] in Riyadh on 5 April, demanding to be employed [[full-time]]. Similar demonstrations took place in [[Taâif]] and [[Tabuk, Saudi Arabia|Tabuk]]. Officials at the Ministry in Riyadh promised to fulfill the demands. ====8 April==== Hundreds of people again protested in Qatif and al-Awamiyah against the use of the Peninsula Shield Force troops from the six Gulf Cooperation Council states against the 2011 Bahraini uprising and for their own political rights and freedoms. ''Thomson Reuters'' stated that no riot police were seen at the Qatif demonstration. ''[[Press TV]]'' said that there was a heavy presence of security forces at both demonstrations, but no clashes or arrests occurred. ====10 April==== On Sunday 10 April, small protests by literacy teachers and unemployed university graduates regarding [[labor rights]] took place in front of the Ministries of Civil Services and Education in Riyadh and the Ministry of Education in Jeddah. [[Facebook]] was used for coordinating one of the protests. ====14â15 April==== Protests against the use of the [[Peninsula Shield Force]] troops in the [[2011 Bahraini uprising]] and for local political rights and freedoms, including the release of prisoners held without trial, again took place in [[Qatif]] and [[al-Awamiyah]] on 14 and 15 April, with about 400â500 protestors in each town and no clashes with police. ====21â22 April==== Protests for similar reasons again took place in Qatif, al-Awamiyah and [[Saihat]] by a few tens to a few hundred protestors. A new complaint made by the protestors was against the destruction of mosques in Bahrain by the Peninsula Shield Force. ====23â25 April==== In a [[civil disobedience]] action from 23â25 April, women in Jeddah, Riyadh and [[Dammam]] tried to register as electors for the [[Saudi Arabian municipal elections, 2011|22 September municipal elections]] despite an official ban against women's participation. The ''[[Gulf News]]'' said that there was "strong public opinion ... supporting women's participation in the election process" following local newspapers' publication of photos of women waiting in queues to register for the election. Fawzia Al Hani, chair of the "Baladi" ''Facebook'' campaign, said that Saudi Arabian law states that women have the right to vote and to stand as candidates. ====29 April==== In the Eastern Province during the days leading up to 29 April, about 20 to 30 people, including two bloggers, were arrested for anti-government activities. On 29 April, a few hundred people demonstrated in Qatif and al-Awamiyah for similar reasons to previous weeks. Five protestors were injured by police in Qatif. ====May==== Street protests in and near Qatif and the beginning of a women's driving campaign took place in May. According to [[Press TV]], hundreds of people protested in Qatif on 5 May, hundreds protested in Qatif and al-Awamiyah on 13 May, and protests occurred in Qatif on 20 May. The protests were against the use of the Peninsula Shield Force troops in the 2011 Bahraini uprising, against the [[arbitrary arrest|arbitrary detention]] of protestors in previous demonstrations, and for improved human rights, especially freedom of speech. During the second week of May 2011, a woman inspired by the [[Arab Spring]], Najla Hariri, started driving a car in Jeddah despite a ''de facto'' ban on women driving. She stated, "Before in Saudi, you never heard about protests. [But] after what has happened in the Middle East, we started to accept a group of people going outside and saying what they want in a loud voice, and this has had an impact on me." On 21 May, [[Manal al-Sharif]], a [[women's rights]] [[activist]] who helped start a women's right to drive campaign, was detained for six hours after a video showing her driving in [[Khobar]] in the [[Eastern Province, Saudi Arabia|Eastern Province]], filmed by another women's rights activist, [[Wajeha al-Huwaider]], gained widespread popularity on [[YouTube]] and [[Facebook]]. Al-Sharif was detained again from 22 May to 30 May, when she was released on [[bail]], on the conditions of returning for questioning if requested, not driving and not talking to the media. ''[[The New York Times]]'' and ''[[Associated Press]]'' associated the long duration of al-Sharif's detention with Saudi authorities' fear of protests. On 23 May, another woman was detained for driving a car. She drove with two women passengers in [[Ar Rass]] and was detained by traffic police in the presence of the [[Committee for the Promotion of Virtue and the Prevention of Vice (Saudi Arabia)|religious police (CPVPV)]]. She was released after signing a statement that she would not drive again. In reaction to al-Sharif's arrest, several more Saudi women published videos of themselves driving during the following days. ====June==== {{main|Women to drive movement}} {{see also|Manal al-Sharif|Wajeha al-Huwaider}} The women's driving campaign continued in June. [[Wajnat Rahbini]], a Saudi actress famous in the Arab world for playing in the satirical comedy ''[[Tash ma Tash]]'', broadcast annually during [[Ramadan]], drove her car "in defiance of a long-standing ban on female driving" on 4 June in Jeddah. She was detained after exiting her car and released the following day without bail. On 17 June, the main date for the women's driving campaign, about 30 to 40 women drove cars in towns around Saudi Arabia, including Maha al-Qahtani and [[Eman al-Nafjan]] in Riyadh, and other women in Jeddah and Dammam. When she drove for a second time the same day, al-Qahtani was given a ticket for driving without a Saudi Arabian licence. ''[[The Guardian]]'' interpreted the lack of arrests as a deliberate change in government policy, stating, "police appeared to be under orders not to intervene." ====October==== On 4 October, there was a firefight between unidentified gunmen and Saudi security personnel in [[Al Qatif]], injuring between 11 police and at least 3 civilians. The government blamed "a foreign country", presumably [[Iran]], for the unrest.{{cite news|url=http://english.alarabiya.net/articles/2011/10/04/170200.html|agency=Al Arabiya|date=4 October 2011|accessdate=4 October 2011|title=Saudi Arabia says a âforeign countryâ is fomenting unrest in Eastern Province}}{{cite news|first=Glen|last=Carey|url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2011-10-04/saudi-security-forces-wounded-in-attack-in-eastern-province.html|date=4 October 2011|accessdate=4 October 2011|agency=Bloomberg Businessweek|title=Saudi Security Forces Wounded in Attack in Eastern Province}} This confrontation grew out of a conflict in al-Awamiyah, a predominantly Shi'a town in the Sunni kingdom, on Sunday when security forces arrested a 60-year-old man to force his son, who was active in a movement to force Saudi Arabia to withdraw from Bahrain, to give himself up. [[Molotov cocktails]] were thrown at the police station.{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/saudi-police-open-fire-on-civilians-as-protests-gain-momentum-2365614.html|title=Suadi Police open fire on civilians}}{{cite new|urlhttp://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052970203388804576612322988969298.htm|Title=Saudis blame foreigners}} ====November==== On 26 November, two people were killed and six others were wounded by police bullets during a protest in [[Qatif]]. http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2011/11/2011112465955365750.html ==Response== ===Domestic=== On 10 February, a [[Thomson Reuters]] report claimed that 10 intellectuals, [[human rights in Saudi Arabia|human rights]] activists and lawyers came together to create the [[Umma Islamic Party]] â considered to be the first political party in Saudi Arabia since the 1990s â to demand the end of [[absolute monarchy]] in the country. On February 18 however, all ten members of the party were arrested and ordered to withdraw demands for political reform in exchange for their release. On 23 February, Saudi Arabia's King Abdullah, after returning to the country following three months spent abroad for health treatment, announced a series of benefits for citizens amounting to $10.7 billion. These include funding to offset high inflation and to aid young unemployed people and Saudi citizens studying abroad, as well the writing off some loans. As part of the Saudi scheme, state employees will see their incomes increase by 15 per cent, and additional cash has also been made available for housing loans. No political reforms were announced as part of the package, though the 86-year-old monarch did pardon some prisoners indicted in financial crimes.{{cite news |title=Saudi king announces new benefits |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/2011223105328424268.html |newspaper=[[Al Jazeera English]] |date=23 February 2011 |accessdate=23 February 2011}} On 6 March, the [[Council of Senior Scholars of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia|Saudi Arabian Council of Senior Scholars]], headed by [[Grand Mufti]] [[Abdul-Azeez ibn Abdullaah Aal ash-Shaikh|Abd al-'Aziz al-Ashaikh]], issued a [[fatwÄ]] (religious opinion) opposing petitions and demonstrations, declaring, "Therefore the council hereby reaffirms that only the reform and [counsel] that has its legitimacy is that which may bring welfare and avert the evil, whereas it is illegal to issue statements and take signatures for the purposes of intimidation and inciting the strife. ... reform should not be by demonstrations and other means and methods that give rise to unrest and divide the community. ... The Council affirms prohibition of the demonstrations in this country and [that] the legal method which realizes the welfare without causing destruction rests on the mutual advice."{{cite web| last =Council of Senior Scholars of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia| first =| authorlink =| coauthors =| title =A fatwa from the Council of Senior Scholars in the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia warning against mass demonstrations | work =| publisher =Islamopediaonline | date=6 March 2011| url =http://islamopediaonline.org/fatwa/fatwa-council-senior-scholars-kingdom-saudi-arabia-warning-against-mass-demonstrations |format =| doi =| accessdate=2 April 2011 |archiveurl= http://www.webcitation.org/5xeKnAzIs |archivedate=2 April 2011 |deadurl=no }}{{cite news | first= | last= | pages= | language =| title=Saudi Arabia prints 1.5m copies of religious edict banning protests | date=29 March 2011 | publisher=The Guardian | url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/mar/29/saudi-arabia-edict-banning-protests |accessdate=2 April 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5xeJz2Dh0 |archivedate=2 April 2011 |deadurl=no }} The fatwa included a "severe threat against internal dissent",{{cite news | first=Irfan | last=al-Alawi | pages= | language =| title=Saudi Arabia's anti-protest fatwa is transparent | date=1 April 2011 | publisher=The Guardian | url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/commentisfree/belief/2011/apr/01/saudi-arabia-anti-protest-fatwa |accessdate=2 April 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5xeLnSw7x |archivedate=2 April 2011 |deadurl=no }} stating, "[The Prophet] again said: 'He who wanted separate affairs of this nation who are unified, you should kill him with sword whoever he is' (narrated by [[Muslim ibn al-Hajjaj Nishapuri|Muslim]])." In late March, Abd al-'Aziz al-Ashaikh called for a million copies of the fatwa to be printed and distributed. On 22â23 March 2011, officials of the [[Council of Ministers of Saudi Arabia|Ministry of Municipal and Rural affairs]] announced that men-only municipal elections to elect half the members of local councils would [[Saudi Arabian municipal elections, 2011|held on 22 September 2011]].{{cite news | first=Abeed | last=al-Suhaimy | pages= | language =| title=Saudi Arabia announces municipal elections | date=23 March 2011 | publisher=[[Asharq al-Awsat]] | url=http://www.aawsat.com/english/news.asp?section=1&id=24616 |accessdate=2 April 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5xePFpuTH |archivedate=2 April 2011 |deadurl=no }}{{cite news | first=Donna | last=Abu-Nasr | pages= | language =| title=Saudi Women Inspired by Fall of Mubarak Step Up Equality Demand | date=28 March 2011 | publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.]] | url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-03-28/saudi-women-inspired-by-revolt-against-mubarak-go-online-to-seek-equality.html |accessdate=2 April 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5xeO2w5aG |archivedate=2 April 2011 |deadurl=no }} ''[[Associated Press]]'' described the election announcement as having "coincided with rumblings of dissent in Saudi Arabia stemming from the wave of political unrest in the Arab world."{{cite news | first= | last= | pages= | language =| title=Saudi Arabia to hold elections next month after year and a half delay | date=22 March 2011 | publisher=[[The Star]]/[[Associated Press|AP]] | url=http://www.thestar.com/news/world/article/958117--saudi-arabia-to-hold-elections-next-month-after-year-and-a-half-delay |accessdate=22 March 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5xNsBXcwF |archivedate=22 March 2011 |deadurl=no }} ;Arrests and other repression About 30 to 50 people were arrested following the 29 January Jeddah demonstration. On 18 February, the ten founding members of the [[Umma Islamic Party]] were arrested and ordered to withdraw demands for political reform in exchange for their release. According to a [[Deutsche Presse-Agentur]] report on 2 March, Saudi activists have alleged that one of the main administrators of one of the [[Facebook]] groups calling for a "Day of Rage" on 11 March, Faisal Ahmed Abdul-Ahad{{cite news | first= | last= | pages= | language =[[German language|German]]| title=Saudi-Arabiens MÃ¤chtige werden nervÃ¶s | date=2 March 2011 | publisher=[[Handelsblatt]]/[[Deutsche Presse-Agentur|DPA]] | url=http://www.handelsblatt.com/politik/international/saudi-arabiens-maechtige-werden-nervoes/3904178.html |accessdate=3 March 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wxnceSVj |archivedate=5 March 2011 |deadurl=no }} (or ''Abdul-Ahadwas''), was killed by [[Ministry of Interior (Saudi Arabia)|Saudi security forces]], who removed his body in order to "hide evidence of the crime".{{cite news | first= | last= | pages= | language =| title=Report: Saudi Facebook activist planning protest shot dead | date=2 March 2011 | publisher=[[Monsters and Critics]]/[[Deutsche Presse-Agentur|DPA]] | url=http://www.monstersandcritics.com/news/middleeast/news/article_1623088.php/Report-Saudi-Facebook-activist-planning-protest-shot-dead |accessdate=2 March 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wtRzehxX |archivedate=2 March 2011 |deadurl=no }}{{cite news | first=Tom | last=Bustamante | pages= | language =| title=Iraq Oil Refinery Attack Shows Need for EarthSearch (ECDC) Systems | date=2 March 2011 | publisher=[[Wall Street Newscast]] | url=http://www.wallstreetnewscast.com/news/2011/march/oil3257.html |accessdate=2 March 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wtRyzFSi |archivedate=2 March 2011 |deadurl=no }} On 5 March, thousands of security forces were sent to the north-east, causing delays on the road to [[Dammam]].{{cite news | first=Robert | last=Fisk | pages= | language =| title=Saudis mobilise thousands of troops to quell growing revolt | date=5 March 2011 | publisher=[[The Independent]] | url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/saudis-mobilise-thousands-of-troops-to-quell-growing-revolt-2232928.html |accessdate=3 March 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wxaC4jgz |archivedate=5 March 2011 |deadurl=no }} On the same day, following about two weeks of small protests in the eastern part of Saudi Arabia, the [[Ministry of Interior (Saudi Arabia)|Ministry of the Interior]] warned that the "ban [on] all sorts of demonstrations, marches, sit-ins" imposed by Saudi law would be enforced.{{cite news | first=Ulf | last=Laessing |coauthors= Matthew Jones | pages= | language =| title=Saudi Arabia says won't tolerate protests | date=5 March 2011 | publisher=[[Thomson Reuters]] | url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/03/05/us-saudi-protests-idUSTRE72419N20110305?sp=true |accessdate=3 March 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wxo8kIog |archivedate=5 March 2011 |deadurl=no }} On 9 March, Foreign Minister [[Saud al-Faisal]] stated that the government would not tolerate any street protests against it, while also saying that the "best way to achieve demands is through national dialogue".{{cite news |title=Thousands stage rally in Bahrain |author=[[Al-Jazeera English]] |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/03/20113917595654981.html |newspaper= |date=9 March 2011 |accessdate=9 March 2011}} On 21 March, [[Saudi Civil and Political Rights Association]] (ACPRA) co-founder Mohammed Saleh Albejadi (also ''Al-Bjady'') was arrested in [[Buraidah]] by [[Mabahith]], the internal security agency. ACPRA stated that the arrest was [[arbitrary arrest|arbitrary]], in violation of the [[Basic Law of Saudi Arabia]] and the ''Law of Criminal Procedures''.{{cite web| last =| first =| authorlink =| coauthors =| title =ACPRA demands the immediate unconditional release of its co-founder, Mohammed Al-Bjady| work =| publisher =[[Saudi Civil and Political Rights Association]] | date=2011-03| url =http://www.acpra.net/news.php?action=list&cat_id=12 |format =| doi =| accessdate=24 March 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5xQmQEnJ2 |archivedate=24 March 2011 |deadurl=no }} {{cite web| last =| first =| authorlink =| coauthors =| title =Human Rights First Society - Human Rights Monitoring and Advocacy in Saudi Arabia | work =| publisher =[[Human Rights First Society]] | date=2011-03| url =http://hrfssaudiarabia.org/ |format =| doi =| accessdate=24 March 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5xQntUChA |archivedate=24 March 2011 |deadurl=no }} Both the ACPRA and [[Human Rights First Society]] called for his immediate, unconditional release. On 27 March, [[Human Rights Watch]] estimated that the "scale of arrests [rose] dramatically during the preceding two weeks", up to about 160 protestors and critics being held without charge. ;Censorship In mid-March, [[Thomson Reuters]]' chief correspondent in Saudi Arabia, Ulf Laessing, who had reported from Riyadh since 2009, had his journalistic accreditation withdrawn because of his reporting on the early 2011 Saudi Arabian protests, effectively forcing him to leave Saudi Arabia.{{cite web| last =| first =| authorlink =| coauthors =| title =Saudi Arabia: Arrests for Peaceful Protest on the Rise| work =| publisher =[[Human Rights Watch]] | date=27 March 2011| url = http://www.hrw.org/en/news/2011/03/27/saudi-arabia-arrests-peaceful-protest-rise|format =| doi =| accessdate=31 March 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5xbOLM8eQ |archivedate=31 March 2011 |deadurl=no }}{{cite news | first=Ulf | last=Laessing |coauthors=Crispian Balmer | pages= | language =| title=Witness - Searching for reforms in King Abdullah's Saudi Arabia | date=24 March 2011 | publisher=[[Thomson Reuters]] | url=http://af.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idAFTRE72N39E20110324?sp=true |accessdate=31 March 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5xbOKqPaU |archivedate=31 March 2011 |deadurl=no }} ===International=== Exiled Saudi physicist and political dissident [[Mohammad al-Massari]] described police attacks on women in the 3 March Qatif demonstration as a strategic error, saying, "They made a stupid mistake by attacking women and so on because they think Shia women do not have ... the honor protection like the rest of the women in the country. But attacking women in Saudi Arabia, in an Islamic country is very severe, very negative and catastrophic ... and this will have dire repercussions." ;Media Journalist [[Robert Fisk]] said that the protests were known as the "Hunayn Revolution,"{{By whom|date=April 2011}} after the [[Battle of Hunayn]] fought between [[Muhammad]] and the [[Hawazin]]. ;Other On 21 February, oil prices rose in response to the [[2011 Libyan uprising]] and speculation regarding the 11 March Saudi Arabian Day of Rage. The Saudi [[Tadawul]] stock market index fell to a seven month low on stability concerns.{{cite web|last=Hankir |first=Zahra |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-03-02/dubai-shares-slump-to-seven-year-low-on-saudi-arabia-concern.html |title=Dubai Stocks Extends Drop on Concern Mideast Unrest May Spread |publisher=Bloomberg |date=3 March 2011 |accessdate=3 April 2011}} On the week of 27 February, global stock prices fell as oil prices increased and silver reached a 30-year high price on stability concerns in the region.{{cite web|last=Regan |first=Michael P. |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-03-02/asian-stocks-fall-as-oil-surges-on-mideast-silver-rises-to-30-year-high.html |title=U.S. Stocks Rise on Job-Market Strength; Oil Jumps, Dollar Falls |publisher=Bloomberg |date=2 March 2011 |accessdate=3 April 2011}} Regional stock market indices also fell on concern for Saudi stability.
